reasoning:
1. Circle of Competence: I’d rather stick to things I know—consumer staples, insurance, banks, railroads and simple industrials. Streaming video is outside my circle of competence. I don’t fully understand the content wars, shifting technology platforms and global licensing agreements well enough to bet billions.
2. Economic Moat: NFLX shows strong operating margins around 48%, but its moat is flimsy. Content libraries and brand recognition matter, yet competitors with deep pockets (Disney, Amazon, HBO) can undercut prices or produce more content. High churn risk and rising programming costs weigh on durability.
3. Management & Capital Allocation: The company has raised equity repeatedly and carries a debt‐to‐equity over 1.3, diluting shareholders and adding financial risk. No dividends or buybacks, just more spending on content—hardly the owner‐oriented stewardship I admire at See’s Candies or Coca-Cola.
4. Financial Health & Consistency: ROE is just 10.9%, ROIC 4.8%, and earnings growth has been lumpy—zero out of ten periods above 15% ROE. For a durable business, I want consistent earnings, not roller-coaster results.
5. Valuation & Margin of Safety: At a negative margin of safety (~–84%), NFLX trades well above the conservative intrinsic value of ~$35,700 (per the three‐stage DCF). Price here vastly exceeds what I’d consider fair, and I’m not keen on paying up for uncertain growth.
6. Long‐Term Prospects & Red Flags: The streaming industry is dynamic and competitive. Content costs keep spiraling, and subscription growth may flatten in mature markets. There’s no reliable pricing power—consumers can jump to a cheaper service or pirate content.
7. Relative Opportunity: Given my portfolio of wide-moat consumer brands, insurance float generators and utilities that raise prices over time, Netflix doesn’t measure up. I’d rather hold a wonderful business at a fair price than a fair business at a wonderful price.
Conclusion: Outside my circle, with shaky moat, uneven results and no margin of safety—I’ll pass on NFLX.

fundamental_analysis.details: Weak ROE of 10.9%; High debt to equity ratio of 1.3; Strong operating margins; Current ratio data not available

consistency_analysis.details: Inconsistent earnings growth pattern; Total earnings growth of 283.9% over past 10 periods

moat_analysis.details: Inconsistent ROE: only 0/10 periods >15%; Strong and stable operating margins (avg: 41.3%) indicate pricing power moat; High performance stability (72.0%) suggests strong competitive moat

book_value_analysis.details: Good book value per share growth pattern

management_analysis.details: Recent common stock issuance (potential dilution); No or minimal dividends paid

details: Using three-stage DCF: Stage 1 (8.0%, 5y), Stage 2 (4.0%, 5y), Terminal (2.5%)
